review_title: Not bad but could be better

Everybody knows the pros and cons of a postdoc regardless of University

Pros:

Flexibility
Benefits (depending of University)
Independence
cons:
NIH salary regardless of state (that means you get same salary not taking into account cost of living of city)
NIH maximum amount of years in post-doc is 5-6 years. After this you are on your own.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA

cons: There is too much focus on the publishing papers versus teaching and actual learning, its just another major research university that is focussed on prestige and not learning.

job_title: Advancement Student Assistant in Seattle, WA

Engineering Advancement:
Pleasant people, quiet office, flexible hours, location on campus.

won't pay all the bills, but it's nice for an undergrad looking for some extra money.
cons: Sometimes not enough work to be done, can be frustrating to try to occupy time with something. Most of the work is mind-numbingly boring too. Generic office clerical stuff.

review_title: Excellent research & people with whom to work

pros: It was a great work environment, my supervisor was very nice so it was easy for me to ask for help if needed.

review_title: Great place to work in a great city

cons: Postdoc positions are typically subject to state or federal research funding. Funding can be inconsistent year-to-year, therefore, you may have to teach classes throughout the year to pay for your salary.

review_title: Good for stability - can be a little tricky for advancement

pros: the work environment is nice, people are friendly, lots of innovation going on in the labs.

pros: very relaxing work environment, good health and vacation benefits, department officers are very supportive.  You can find many resouces about career development.

review_title: Great organization but could use better managers

review_title: Great place to work, student pay not great

review_title: Not at all what I expected.
pros:
Seattle's largest employer?
Smart co-workers.
Work can be intellectually stimulating at times.
New, privately funded football stadium on the way (yes, I'm reaching for benefits here).
cons:
University funding is tied to Washington State's budget cuts.
Benefits are terrible (you pay for every "benefit" out of pocket, i.e. health care premiums, gym membership, transit/parking pass).
Clueless senior management.
No chance at being recognized for great job performance, either through bonuses or staff recognition.
Mark Emmert left UW earlier this year.
